question.firstquestionhead: Mathematical Functions >>> IF INTEGER :: x = 4 >>> Conversion Functions >>> Assume x = 7.8 and y = -8.8 >>> Other functions
question.firstquestiontext: COS (X) --> cosine of X radian. SIN (X) --> sine of X radian TAN (X) --> tangent of X radian ACOS (X) --> the inverse cosine (in radian) ASIN (X) --> the inverse sine (in radian) ATAN (X) --> the inverse tangent in radian EXP (X) --> exponential e^x SQRT (X) --> square root of X LOG (X) --> the natural logarithm of X LOG10 (X) --> the common logarithmic of X (base 10)>>>sqrt(x) = ---ERROR--- >>> INT(x) --> truncate to integer partx --> INT(-3.5) = -3 NINT(x) --> round nearest integer to x --> NINT(3.5) = 4 FLOOR(x) --> greatest integer less than or equal to x --> FLOOR(-3.5) = -4 FRACTION(x) --> the fractional part of x --> FRACTION(12.3)= 0.3 REAL(x) --> convert x to REAL --> REAL(-10) = 10.0 >>> FLOOR(x)= ---7--- ---FRACTION(x)= ---.8--- ---FLOOR(y)= --- -9 --- >>> MAX(x1, x2, ..., xn) --> maximum of x1, x2, ... xn MIN(x1 x2 xn) --> minimum of x1, x2, ... xn
question.secondquestionhead: List-Directed (READ) >>> Complete to read I,J,K from user's input
question.secondquestiontext: Fortran uses the READ(*,*)statement read data into variables from keyboard: READ(*,*)always starts with a new line Example: READ(*,*) v1 v2 vn READ(,) v1,v2, â€¦,vn CHARACTER(LEN=5) :: Name REAL :: height, count READ(*,*) Name,height,count Smith 100.0 25 READ(*,*) I, J, K 100,300,400, 500 !here I = 100 .. J = 300 .. K = 400 and 500 will be ignore >>> ---READ(*,*)--- I,J,K >>>
question.thirdquestionhead: List-Directed WRITE >>> What is the output of this program CHARACTER:: Name = "Smith" Write(*,*) Name End program
question.thirdquestiontext: Fortran uses the WRITE(*,*)statement to write information to screen. -WRITE(*,*)always starts with a new line! Example: REAL :: x=5. WRITE(*,*) x End program here output is 5. >>> ---S--- >>>
question.fourthquestiontext: Program hello-world WRITE(*,*) "Hello World" END program
question.gridtext: Fortran Intrinsic Functions >>> Getting User Input >>> WRITE(*,*) >>> A Hello World Program
